source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: Our investigations were performed within tube furnaces in the range 600 to 1300°C for up to 15 min [11].

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: Parabolic functions were measured for oxygen uptake (Fig. 3) and ZrO₂, α-Zr(O), and combined layers growth, valid above 1000°C but applicable as approximation at lower temperatures as well.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: A trend towards cubic kinetics was observed below 1000°C due to a transformation of the oxide structure. The gradual change to cubic kinetics is finally reached at and below about 800°C.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: The calculated times of exposure at which under isothermal conditions a metallic tube would have taken up the maximum allowed amount of oxygen on its inner and outer surface for calculated 17% total wall consumption are 20 min at 1100°C, 8 min at 1200°C, and 4 min at 1300°C.

evidence_span: The calculated times of exposure at which under isothermal conditions a metallic tube would have taken up the maximum allowed amount of oxygen on its inner and outer surface for calculated 17% total wall consumption are 20 min at 1100°C, 8 min at 1200°C, and 4 min at 1300°C.

evidence_span: The calculated times of exposure at which under isothermal conditions a metallic tube would have taken up the maximum allowed amount of oxygen on its inner and outer surface for calculated 17% total wall consumption are 20 min at 1100°C, 8 min at 1200°C, and 4 min at 1300°C.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: Pre-existing oxide scales, artificially prepared by steam exposure to simulate in-reactor grown oxide scales, showed a protective effect which vanished by excessive scale growth and at temperatures above 1100°C.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: The results prove a remarkable difference between our isothermal results and those obtained in the course of the three min-transients. Expressed in percentages, a reduction of a quarter (1100 to 1200°C) to one third (900 to 1000°C) in oxygen uptake than under isothermal conditions (Fig. 6) was measured.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: The results prove a remarkable difference between our isothermal results and those obtained in the course of the three min-transients. Expressed in percentages, a reduction of a quarter (1100 to 1200°C) to one third (900 to 1000°C) in oxygen uptake than under isothermal conditions (Fig. 6) was measured.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk2
evidence_span: As in the isothermal exposure, the protective effect of pre-existent scales degrades above 1100°C, but under transient conditions a broad scatter in local behavior precludes a reliable deterministic evaluation, especially of the anticipated in-pile response.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk5
evidence_span: Small azimuthal temperature differences on the cladding tube cause a relatively homogeneous decrease of the cladding tube wall thickness along the circumference and, consequently, lead to relatively large burst strains; large azimuthal temperature differences occurring in the course of deformation lead to a preferred reduction in wall thickness on the hot part only of the cladding tube circumference and hence to relatively low burst strains

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: Figure 30 shows corresponding plots for a blockage ratio of $90 \%$ in the blocked region. It is evident that under these severe conditions the coolant mass flow reduction overshadows the twophase cooling enhancement effect. However, the temperature rise downstream of the blockage and the delay in quench time are moderate.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: The Baker-Just equation describes the oxidation kinetics in a very conservative manner.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: The extent of oxidation stays within the $1 7 \%$ limit of the ECC criteria even after extended preoxidation and transient exposure at maximum temperature ( $1 0 \  \mathrm { m i n }$ $1 2 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C } )$ .

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: The circumferential burst strain of the cladding is kept relatively small due to temperature differences on the cladding circumference.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: The cooling effect of the ECCS increases temperature differences on the cladding tube circumference and limits in this way the mean circumferential average burst strains in bundles to values around $50 \%$ .

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: Unidirectional coolant flow during the refilling and reflooding phases results in the highest possible flow blockage of approximately $70 \%$ .

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: Thermal-hydraulic analyses of the emergency core cooling by pessimistic evaluation models show that in a PWR the majority of the fuel rods reach peak cladding temperatures lower than ${ 7 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ and that only the relatively few high-rated fuel rods which represent less than $1 \%$ in the whole reactor core attain peak cladding temperatures of approximately $1 0 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: Thermal-hydraulic analyses of the emergency core cooling by pessimistic evaluation models show that in a PWR the majority of the fuel rods reach peak cladding temperatures lower than ${ 7 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ and that only the relatively few high-rated fuel rods which represent less than $1 \%$ in the whole reactor core attain peak cladding temperatures of approximately $1 0 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: The percentage of fuel rods with peak cladding temperatures above ${ \bf 8 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ is less than $1 0 \%$ .
property_name: percentage of fuel rods with peak cladding temperature >800°C

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: The internal rod pressure of prepressurized PWR fuel rod claddings in a LOCA is calculated to be around 60 bar, depending on the fuel rod design and burnup

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_037_chunk10
evidence_span: the time at maximum cladding temperatures is limited to less than $3 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ due to the high efficiency of the emergency core cooling systems.
